occupation.title: Human Resources Managers
occupation.description: Plan, direct, or coordinate human resources activities and staff of an organization.

task.name: Serve as a link between management and employees by handling questions, interpreting and administering contracts and helping resolve work-related problems.
Analyze and modify compensation and benefits policies to establish competitive programs and ensure compliance with legal requirements.
Advise managers on organizational policy matters, such as equal employment opportunity and sexual harassment, and recommend needed changes.
Perform difficult staffing duties, including dealing with understaffing, refereeing disputes, firing employees, and administering disciplinary procedures.
Plan and conduct new employee orientation to foster positive attitude toward organizational objectives.
Identify staff vacancies and recruit, interview and select applicants.
Plan, direct, supervise, and coordinate work activities of subordinates and staff relating to employment, compensation, labor relations, and employee relations.
Plan, organize, direct, control, or coordinate the personnel, training, or labor relations activities of an organization.
Represent organization at personnel-related hearings and investigations.
Administer compensation, benefits and performance management systems, and safety and recreation programs.
Provide current and prospective employees with information about policies, job duties, working conditions, wages, opportunities for promotion, and employee benefits.
Analyze statistical data and reports to identify and determine causes of personnel problems and develop recommendations for improvement of organization's personnel policies and practices.
Prepare and follow budgets for personnel operations.
Maintain records and compile statistical reports concerning personnel-related data such as hires, transfers, performance appraisals, and absenteeism rates.
Analyze training needs to design employee development, language training, and health and safety programs.
Conduct exit interviews to identify reasons for employee termination.
Oversee the evaluation, classification and rating of occupations and job positions.
Prepare personnel forecast to project employment needs.
Study legislation, arbitration decisions, and collective bargaining contracts to assess industry trends.
Allocate human resources, ensuring appropriate matches between personnel.
Develop or administer special projects in areas such as pay equity, savings bond programs, day care, and employee awards.
Negotiate bargaining agreements and help interpret labor contracts.
Investigate and report on industrial accidents for insurance carriers.

title.name: Data base user interface and query software
Business intelligence and data analysis software
Web page creation and editing software
Data base user interface and query software
Business intelligence and data analysis software
Web page creation and editing software

element.name: Personnel and Human Resources
element.description: Knowledge of principles and procedures for personnel recruitment, selection, training, compensation and benefits, labor relations and negotiation, and personnel information systems.

element.name: Administration and Management
element.description: Knowledge of business and management principles involved in strategic planning, resource allocation, human resources modeling, leadership technique, production methods, and coordination of people and resources.

element.name: English Language
element.description: Knowledge of the structure and content of the English language including the meaning and spelling of words, rules of composition, and grammar.

element.name: Customer and Personal Service
element.description: Knowledge of principles and processes for providing customer and personal services. This includes customer needs assessment, meeting quality standards for services, and evaluation of customer satisfaction.

element.name: Law and Government
element.description: Knowledge of laws, legal codes, court procedures, precedents, government regulations, executive orders, agency rules, and the democratic political process.

element.name: Psychology
element.description: Knowledge of human behavior and performance; individual differences in ability, personality, and interests; learning and motivation; psychological research methods; and the assessment and treatment of behavioral and affective disorders.

element.name: Education and Training
element.description: Knowledge of principles and methods for curriculum and training design, teaching and instruction for individuals and groups, and the measurement of training effects.

element.name: Mathematics
element.description: Knowledge of arithmetic, algebra, geometry, calculus, statistics, and their applications.

element.name: Active Listening
element.description: Giving full attention to what other people are saying, taking time to understand the points being made, asking questions as appropriate, and not interrupting at inappropriate times.

element.name: Management of Personnel Resources
element.description: Motivating, developing, and directing people as they work, identifying the best people for the job.

element.name: Social Perceptiveness
element.description: Being aware of others' reactions and understanding why they react as they do.

element.name: Speaking
element.description: Talking to others to convey information effectively.

element.name: Coordination
element.description: Adjusting actions in relation to others' actions.

element.name: Critical Thinking
element.description: Using logic and reasoning to identify the strengths and weaknesses of alternative solutions, conclusions or approaches to problems.

element.name: Reading Comprehension
element.description: Understanding written sentences and paragraphs in work related documents.

element.name: Judgment and Decision Making
element.description: Considering the relative costs and benefits of potential actions to choose the most appropriate one.

element.name: Negotiation
element.description: Bringing others together and trying to reconcile differences.

element.name: Complex Problem Solving
element.description: Identifying complex problems and reviewing related information to develop and evaluate options and implement solutions.

element.name: Monitoring
element.description: Monitoring/Assessing performance of yourself, other individuals, or organizations to make improvements or take corrective action.

element.name: Persuasion
element.description: Persuading others to change their minds or behavior.

element.name: Systems Analysis
element.description: Determining how a system should work and how changes in conditions, operations, and the environment will affect outcomes.

element.name: Systems Evaluation
element.description: Identifying measures or indicators of system performance and the actions needed to improve or correct performance, relative to the goals of the system.

element.name: Time Management
element.description: Managing one's own time and the time of others.

element.name: Active Learning
element.description: Understanding the implications of new information for both current and future problem-solving and decision-making.

element.name: Writing
element.description: Communicating effectively in writing as appropriate for the needs of the audience.

element.name: Instructing
element.description: Teaching others how to do something.

element.name: Service Orientation
element.description: Actively looking for ways to help people.

element.name: Learning Strategies
element.description: Selecting and using training/instructional methods and procedures appropriate for the situation when learning or teaching new things.

element.name: Oral Comprehension
element.description: The ability to listen to and understand information and ideas presented through spoken words and sentences.

element.name: Written Comprehension
element.description: The ability to read and understand information and ideas presented in writing.

element.name: Oral Expression
element.description: The ability to communicate information and ideas in speaking so others will understand.

element.name: Speech Recognition
element.description: The ability to identify and understand the speech of another person.

element.name: Written Expression
element.description: The ability to communicate information and ideas in writing so others will understand.

element.name: Deductive Reasoning
element.description: The ability to apply general rules to specific problems to produce answers that make sense.

element.name: Speech Clarity
element.description: The ability to speak clearly so others can understand you.

element.name: Inductive Reasoning
element.description: The ability to combine pieces of information to form general rules or conclusions (includes finding a relationship among seemingly unrelated events).

element.name: Problem Sensitivity
element.description: The ability to tell when something is wrong or is likely to go wrong. It does not involve solving the problem, only recognizing there is a problem.

element.name: Fluency of Ideas
element.description: The ability to come up with a number of ideas about a topic (the number of ideas is important, not their quality, correctness, or creativity).

element.name: Information Ordering
element.description: The ability to arrange things or actions in a certain order or pattern according to a specific rule or set of rules (e.g., patterns of numbers, letters, words, pictures, mathematical operations).

element.name: Originality
element.description: The ability to come up with unusual or clever ideas about a given topic or situation, or to develop creative ways to solve a problem.

element.name: Category Flexibility
element.description: The ability to generate or use different sets of rules for combining or grouping things in different ways.

element.name: Near Vision
element.description: The ability to see details at close range (within a few feet of the observer).

element.name: Selective Attention
element.description: The ability to concentrate on a task over a period of time without being distracted.

element.name: Communicating with Supervisors, Peers, or Subordinates
element.description: Providing information to supervisors, co-workers, and subordinates by telephone, in written form, e-mail, or in person.

element.name: Resolving Conflicts and Negotiating with Others
element.description: Handling complaints, settling disputes, and resolving grievances and conflicts, or otherwise negotiating with others.

element.name: Establishing and Maintaining Interpersonal Relationships
element.description: Developing constructive and cooperative working relationships with others, and maintaining them over time.

element.name: Making Decisions and Solving Problems
element.description: Analyzing information and evaluating results to choose the best solution and solve problems.

element.name: Evaluating Information to Determine Compliance with Standards
element.description: Using relevant information and individual judgment to determine whether events or processes comply with laws, regulations, or standards.

element.name: Judging the Qualities of Things, Services, or People
element.description: Assessing the value, importance, or quality of things or people.

element.name: Getting Information
element.description: Observing, receiving, and otherwise obtaining information from all relevant sources.

element.name: Developing and Building Teams
element.description: Encouraging and building mutual trust, respect, and cooperation among team members.

element.name: Updating and Using Relevant Knowledge
element.description: Keeping up-to-date technically and applying new knowledge to your job.

element.name: Staffing Organizational Units
element.description: Recruiting, interviewing, selecting, hiring, and promoting employees in an organization.

element.name: Provide Consultation and Advice to Others
element.description: Providing guidance and expert advice to management or other groups on technical, systems-, or process-related topics.

element.name: Interacting With Computers
element.description: Using computers and computer systems (including hardware and software) to program, write software, set up functions, enter data, or process information.

element.name: Communicating with Persons Outside Organization
element.description: Communicating with people outside the organization, representing the organization to customers, the public, government, and other external sources. This information can be exchanged in person, in writing, or by telephone or e-mail.

element.name: Coaching and Developing Others
element.description: Identifying the developmental needs of others and coaching, mentoring, or otherwise helping others to improve their knowledge or skills.

element.name: Interpreting the Meaning of Information for Others
element.description: Translating or explaining what information means and how it can be used.

element.name: Coordinating the Work and Activities of Others
element.description: Getting members of a group to work together to accomplish tasks.

element.name: Identifying Objects, Actions, and Events
element.description: Identifying information by categorizing, estimating, recognizing differences or similarities, and detecting changes in circumstances or events.

element.name: Organizing, Planning, and Prioritizing Work
element.description: Developing specific goals and plans to prioritize, organize, and accomplish your work.

element.name: Developing Objectives and Strategies
element.description: Establishing long-range objectives and specifying the strategies and actions to achieve them.

element.name: Processing Information
element.description: Compiling, coding, categorizing, calculating, tabulating, auditing, or verifying information or data.

element.name: Analyzing Data or Information
element.description: Identifying the underlying principles, reasons, or facts of information by breaking down information or data into separate parts.

element.name: Documenting/Recording Information
element.description: Entering, transcribing, recording, storing, or maintaining information in written or electronic/magnetic form.

element.name: Thinking Creatively
element.description: Developing, designing, or creating new applications, ideas, relationships, systems, or products, including artistic contributions.

element.name: Guiding, Directing, and Motivating Subordinates
element.description: Providing guidance and direction to subordinates, including setting performance standards and monitoring performance.

element.name: Training and Teaching Others
element.description: Identifying the educational needs of others, developing formal educational or training programs or classes, and teaching or instructing others.

element.name: Assisting and Caring for Others
element.description: Providing personal assistance, medical attention, emotional support, or other personal care to others such as coworkers, customers, or patients.

element.name: Monitoring and Controlling Resources
element.description: Monitoring and controlling resources and overseeing the spending of money.

element.name: Scheduling Work and Activities
element.description: Scheduling events, programs, and activities, as well as the work of others.

element.name: Selling or Influencing Others
element.description: Convincing others to buy merchandise/goods or to otherwise change their minds or actions.

element.name: Monitor Processes, Materials, or Surroundings
element.description: Monitoring and reviewing information from materials, events, or the environment, to detect or assess problems.

element.name: Performing Administrative Activities
element.description: Performing day-to-day administrative tasks such as maintaining information files and processing paperwork.

activity.name: Liaise between departments or other groups to improve function or communication.
Analyze data to inform operational decisions or activities.
Advise others on legal or regulatory compliance matters.
Recommend organizational process or policy changes.
Interview employees, customers, or others to collect information.
Represent the organization in external relations.
Analyze data to inform personnel decisions.
Prepare reports related to compliance matters.
Maintain knowledge of current developments in area of expertise.
Advise others on career or personal development.
Negotiate sales or lease agreements for products or services.

element.name: Electronic Mail
element.description: How often do you use electronic mail in this job?

element.name: Telephone
element.description: How often do you have telephone conversations in this job?

element.name: Face-to-Face Discussions
element.description: How often do you have to have face-to-face discussions with individuals or teams in this job?

element.name: Duration of Typical Work Week
element.description: Number of hours typically worked in one week.

element.name: Freedom to Make Decisions
element.description: How much decision making freedom, without supervision, does the job offer?

element.name: Indoors, Environmentally Controlled
element.description: How often does this job require working indoors in environmentally controlled conditions?

element.name: Structured versus Unstructured Work
element.description: To what extent is this job structured for the worker, rather than allowing the worker to determine tasks, priorities, and goals?

element.name: Contact With Others
element.description: How much does this job require the worker to be in contact with others (face-to-face, by telephone, or otherwise) in order to perform it?

element.name: Letters and Memos
element.description: How often does the job require written letters and memos?

element.name: Spend Time Sitting
element.description: How much does this job require sitting?

element.name: Work With Work Group or Team
element.description: How important is it to work with others in a group or team in this job?

element.name: Impact of Decisions on Co-workers or Company Results
element.description: What results do your decisions usually have on other people or the image or reputation or financial resources of your employer?

element.name: Frequency of Conflict Situations
element.description: How often are there conflict situations the employee has to face in this job?

response.name: Once a week or more but not every day

element.name: Importance of Being Exact or Accurate
element.description: How important is being very exact or highly accurate in performing this job?

element.name: Frequency of Decision Making
element.description: How frequently is the worker required to make decisions that affect other people, the financial resources, and/or the image and reputation of the organization?

element.name: Coordinate or Lead Others
element.description: How important is it to coordinate or lead others in accomplishing work activities in this job?

element.name: Time Pressure
element.description: How often does this job require the worker to meet strict deadlines?

response.name: Once a week or more but not every day

element.name: Responsible for Others' Health and Safety
element.description: How much responsibility is there for the health and safety of others in this job?

element.name: Deal With Unpleasant or Angry People
element.description: How frequently does the worker have to deal with unpleasant, angry, or discourteous individuals as part of the job requirements?

response.name: Once a month or more but not every week

element.name: Responsibility for Outcomes and Results
element.description: How responsible is the worker for work outcomes and results of other workers?

element.name: Consequence of Error
element.description: How serious would the result usually be if the worker made a mistake that was not readily correctable?

element.name: Level of Competition
element.description: To what extent does this job require the worker to compete or to be aware of competitive pressures?

job_zone.title: Job Zone Four: Considerable Preparation Needed
job_zone.education: Most of these occupations require a four-year bachelor's degree, but some do not.
job_zone.related_experience: A considerable amount of work-related skill, knowledge, or experience is needed for these occupations. For example, an accountant must complete four years of college and work for several years in accounting to be considered qualified.
job_zone.job_training: Employees in these occupations usually need several years of work-related experience, on-the-job training, and/or vocational training.
job_zone.job_zone_examples: Many of these occupations involve coordinating, supervising, managing, or training others. Examples include accountants, sales managers, database administrators, graphic designers, chemists, art directors, and cost estimators.

category.name: Post-baccalaureate certificate
category.description: Awarded for completion of an organized program of study; designed for people who have completed a Baccalaureate degree, but do not meet the requirements of academic degrees carrying the title of Master

element.name: Enterprising
element.description: Enterprising occupations frequently involve starting up and carrying out projects. These occupations can involve leading people and making many decisions. Sometimes they require risk taking and often deal with business.

element.name: Social
element.description: Social occupations frequently involve working with, communicating with, and teaching people. These occupations often involve helping or providing service to others.

element.name: Conventional
element.description: Conventional occupations frequently involve following set procedures and routines. These occupations can include working with data and details more than with ideas. Usually there is a clear line of authority to follow.

element.name: Integrity
element.description: Job requires being honest and ethical.

element.name: Stress Tolerance
element.description: Job requires accepting criticism and dealing calmly and effectively with high stress situations.

element.name: Leadership
element.description: Job requires a willingness to lead, take charge, and offer opinions and direction.

element.name: Dependability
element.description: Job requires being reliable, responsible, and dependable, and fulfilling obligations.

element.name: Initiative
element.description: Job requires a willingness to take on responsibilities and challenges.

element.name: Self Control
element.description: Job requires maintaining composure, keeping emotions in check, controlling anger, and avoiding aggressive behavior, even in very difficult situations.

element.name: Adaptability/Flexibility
element.description: Job requires being open to change (positive or negative) and to considerable variety in the workplace.

element.name: Concern for Others
element.description: Job requires being sensitive to others' needs and feelings and being understanding and helpful on the job.

element.name: Cooperation
element.description: Job requires being pleasant with others on the job and displaying a good-natured, cooperative attitude.

element.name: Persistence
element.description: Job requires persistence in the face of obstacles.

element.name: Analytical Thinking
element.description: Job requires analyzing information and using logic to address work-related issues and problems.

element.name: Attention to Detail
element.description: Job requires being careful about detail and thorough in completing work tasks.

element.name: Social Orientation
element.description: Job requires preferring to work with others rather than alone, and being personally connected with others on the job.

element.name: Independence
element.description: Job requires developing one's own ways of doing things, guiding oneself with little or no supervision, and depending on oneself to get things done.

element.name: Achievement/Effort
element.description: Job requires establishing and maintaining personally challenging achievement goals and exerting effort toward mastering tasks.

element.name: Innovation
element.description: Job requires creativity and alternative thinking to develop new ideas for and answers to work-related problems.

element.name: Relationships
element.description: Occupations that satisfy this work value allow employees to provide service to others and work with co-workers in a friendly non-competitive environment. Corresponding needs are Co-workers, Moral Values and Social Service.

element.name: Recognition
element.description: Occupations that satisfy this work value offer advancement, potential for leadership, and are often considered prestigious. Corresponding needs are Advancement, Authority, Recognition and Social Status.

element.name: Working Conditions
element.description: Occupations that satisfy this work value offer job security and good working conditions. Corresponding needs are Activity, Compensation, Independence, Security, Variety and Working Conditions.

source.name: American Society for Healthcare Human Resources Administration
College and University Professional Association for Human Resources
International Public Management Association for Human Resources
Occupational Outlook Handbook: Human resources managers
